claim: France uses the euro as its official currency

supporting.text: France is a member of the European Union, which adopted the euro as its official currency.

attacks.text: France is a member of the European Union, which adopted the euro as its official currency.
Some EU member states, like Denmark, have opt-outs and do not use the euro.
France does not have an opt-out and is part of the Eurozone, which mandates the use of the euro.
France could theoretically leave the EU or the Eurozone in the future, abandoning the euro.
There is no current political or economic indication that France plans to leave the EU or the Eurozone.

supporting.text: The euro has been the legal tender in France since its introduction in 1999.

attacks.text: The euro has been the legal tender in France since its introduction in 1999.
France still allows limited use of the French franc in certain overseas territories.
The use of the French franc in overseas territories is extremely rare and not considered part of France's official currency system.
Some businesses in border regions unofficially accept Swiss francs or other currencies.
Unofficial acceptance of other currencies doesn't change the fact that the euro is France's only official legal tender.

supporting.text: French law designates the euro as the sole official currency for all transactions within the country.

attacks.text: French law designates the euro as the sole official currency for all transactions within the country.
Some overseas territories of France, such as French Polynesia, use the CFP franc instead of the euro.
The CFP franc is pegged to the euro and is effectively a local variant of the euro, not a fully independent currency.
Certain businesses in border regions may unofficially accept other currencies like the Swiss franc or US dollar.
Such practices are exceptions and not legally recognized; the euro remains the only official currency.

supporting.text: The Banque de France, as part of the Eurosystem, issues and manages the euro in France.

attacks.text: The Banque de France, as part of the Eurosystem, issues and manages the euro in France.
France used the franc before 2002 and some territories still use other currencies.
The franc was fully replaced by the euro in 2002, and all official transactions are conducted in euros.
Some French overseas territories, like French Polynesia, use the CFP franc instead of the euro.
These territories are not part of the European Union and thus their currency does not affect the official status of the euro in metropolitan France.
